subs.text: February 24
“Great poetry lives in a state of perpetual transformation, perpetual translation: the poem dies when it has no place to go.” —Eliot Weinberger, Nineteen Ways of Looking at Wang Wei
subs.rawText: “Great poetry lives in a state of perpetual transformation, perpetual translation: the poem dies when it has no place to go.” —Eliot Weinberger, Nineteen Ways of Looking at Wang Wei

subs.text: I don't mean to idealize the past, since people with a good memory can easily recall no shortage of abominable behavior, but there have been groups of people who have tried to share responsibility for disseminating worthy information online.
subs.rawText: I don't mean to idealize the past, since people with a good memory can easily recall no shortage of abominable behavior, but there have been groups of people who have tried to share responsibility for disseminating worthy information online.

subs.text: Fifteen or twenty years ago it was commonly understood that a community of bloggers with a shared interest acted like a team of information screeners. When something was published that mattered to fans of their shared topic, someone in the group would notice.
subs.rawText: Fifteen or twenty years ago it was commonly understood that a community of bloggers with a shared interest acted like a team of information screeners. When something was published that mattered to fans of their shared topic, someone in the group would notice.

subs.text: Having noticed, one or more people would skim or read well, comment shallowly or thoughtfully, add a link, and spread the word in the community. If the thing was really promising, a second wave of readers would build on the early notices with further thoughts of their own.
subs.rawText: Having noticed, one or more people would skim or read well, comment shallowly or thoughtfully, add a link, and spread the word in the community. If the thing was really promising, a second wave of readers would build on the early notices with further thoughts of their own.

subs.text: There would be arguments of fact and interpretation, and the new item would begin to enter the tested and perhaps taken-for-granted contents of the community's hive mind. It might be improved in the process.
subs.rawText: There would be arguments of fact and interpretation, and the new item would begin to enter the tested and perhaps taken-for-granted contents of the community's hive mind. It might be improved in the process.

subs.text: Being the blogosphere, traces of the shared work would make their way down the many screens into archives, becoming less useful there as days went by. Some people would have been informed and perhaps energized. Maybe they'd try something new out in the world. Or maybe not.
subs.rawText: Being the blogosphere, traces of the shared work would make their way down the many screens into archives, becoming less useful there as days went by. Some people would have been informed and perhaps energized. Maybe they'd try something new out in the world. Or maybe not.

subs.text:
Just crept above 32 degrees here in northern Indiana.

Our older neighbor with the big, skinny, long-haired dog ambled by in his winter coat, yellow whiffle ball bat in hand in case any off-leash pups approach. It’s a long story.

subs.text: After a beautiful concert, I accidentally insulted the pianist, saying the performance was lovely and so athletic. Disapproval flashed on her face as she repeated the word athletic. (In my defense: there had been some wiping of the brow.) The nearby violinist did not comment. [link]

subs.text: February 22

@TheRaDR I remember my daughter and her friend sitting at the table mocking their junior high health book because they plainly saw how terrified the book/the society was of human bodies. They saw the book twist slyly away from discussing what they cared about. They mocked and mocked it.
subs.rawText: @TheRaDR I remember my daughter and her friend sitting at the table mocking their junior high health book because they plainly saw how terrified the book/the society was of human bodies. They saw the book twist slyly away from discussing what they cared about. They mocked and mocked it.

subs.text: @TheRaDR They saw, on some level, that the society was in the process of abandoning them and betraying them.
subs.rawText: @TheRaDR They saw, on some level, that the society was in the process of abandoning them and betraying them.

subs.text: February 21

Some ways of telling the story feel disempowering.

And so they probably are.

It’s worth figuring out why that is.

The tragic and fearful character of our times is not something from which we can detach ourselves; we are in it, as fish are in the sea, whether we speak about it in our poems or not.”

—Denise Levertov, a #SundaySentence

subs.text: “At fifteen, I read a piece about the all-woman noise trio Babes in Toyland and knew the critic got it wrong and that I, a fan, could get it right. [My] entrance to music criticism was a rebuttal [and] much of my early career was me yelling But you’re wrong! over the transom.” [link]

A brief report back from the afterlife. From “Angels & Saints” by Eliot Weinberger. [link]
What is the journey of advanced old age? Observing her own mother closely, poet Denise Levertov reports a few things about the life of some or many elders. [link]
February 18
Science and science communication, social media, creativity, inclusivity, and drag. [link]

Eleven years ago today…

Out front, a yard or so of gray-black snow has melted down to the ground, revealing a snow-drowned Ophelia near the curb:  the green, prone, flattened shape of our Christmas tree.

Early on a sunny Paris evening, summer of 1982, I set out to visit Père Lachaise Cemetery, but when I arrived it had already closed for the day. Dozens of famous people are buried there, but oddly I can no longer remember whose grave I planned to visit. Not the rock star, though. [link]

@princessekateri @holdengraber Jack Gilbert said a noun can be "a pretend-noun, a noun that turns out to be a trope," while others are real nouns: "I can bite them like people used to bite coins to see if they were genuine." From his letter to Fr. Alberto Huerta, entitled "Real Nouns"... [link]
@princessekateri @holdengraber Not so easy to find the "Real Nouns" letter by Jack Gilbert. [link]
February 17

“Users have a special kind of insight that most news organizations don’t tap…. The challenge for news organizations [is] to learn how to incorporate the experience of these users and their new publishing tools, into their product — the news.” [link]
@RayBoomhower Thanks for bringing Jack Gilbert to mind today, by the way.
@RayBoomhower Since you have written quite a bit about war and war writing, I wonder what you might think of Jack Gilbert’s poem “The Abnormal is not Courage”?
@RayBoomhower I’m tempted to say it’s clever rhetoric that obscures as much as it reveals about courage.
@RayBoomhower @Son_of_Sandor …chronicles one more way war tears at everything it touches…

‘The book – the actual physical paper bound object full of words – is a treasure in this modern era. A book contains an entire universe you can only bring to life in your imagination, if you agree to give it time. It is a tribute to privacy, an honouring of the interior life.’ [link]
From Still Reading, an exhibition of paintings by Nancy Cadogan and sculptures by Martin Jennings. (Cadogan’s words and image detail above.) [link]
February 16

Celebrities often accept money for promoting products.

But in recent FTX_Official commercials, Larry David goes a step further, portraying people who have doubts about "visionary" things like cryptocurrency and non-fungible tokens as buffoons.

In The Big Lebowski, Walter says, "This is bowling, there are rules." The alternative, he proposes, is the rule-less waste of warfare, which he was messed up by, in Vietnam.

Implied, maybe, is a third state: an institution that appears to have rules but down deep does not.
In Beowulf's time, a desirable guy was someone ready to tear the arm off whatever monster came crawling out of the darkness toward the village hall, or die trying.

One activism move now seems to be helping corporations understand that the people complaining, the activists asking for something different from them, are also their customers. [link]

An obvious example is a House of Representatives where we already know which party will win in maybe 90% of the districts in 2022.

A language shimmers weblike in people’s minds. Some sentences retrace its reliable associations, but others test and even scorn them, tearing and reweaving as they go. [link]

With some jokes, the audience is meant to spot the punch line before it arrives. This is fun and flattering for everyone in the room. A brief example from Mitch Hedberg starts at 0:32 here. [link]
This morning, on the exercise bike for 43 minutes, via Kanopy, a full Buster Keaton film from 1924. Lots of public libraries offer Kanopy. [link]
@IlanYLevine As John Lennon sang, "There's nothing you can do that can't be done." [link]
“Whatever you’re meant to do, do it now. The conditions are always impossible.” —Doris Lessing [link]

Judging by her silence, IN-2nd's @RepWalorski / @JackieWalorski agrees with the RNC that the violence of January 6, 2021 was an ordinary, appropriate kind of public protest,

OR she's afraid to disagree with powerful party forces.

Neither is a good sign. Time to send her home.
"Too much focus on being a hero, inflating the avatar, which ultimately kills the creativity." [link]
Our norms of violence. Denise Levertov on the normal, institutionalized forms of violence by which we were destroying our chances for a shared future. [link]
February 8

In a rightly spoiler-filled episode on The Power of the Dog, @thehighsign and @bloomer unpack everything, I think, except THIS spoiler:

The man who knew how to torment every other person spent ages braiding a rope to give to the person most likely to be haunted brutally by it.
Having seen The Power of the Dog, I enjoyed thinking along with the hosts during this spoiler-filled podcast episode. [link]
At our wedding, a friend filled the rafters with her voice alone carrying the melody and poetry of “How Can I Keep From Singing?” [link]

“With a world [connected yet volatile] with a constant sense of fracturing identities, Tamim Ansary contends that our shared history is a story we must invent. And the future of our species depends on our ability to develop a story we can all see ourselves in.” [link]
February 7

We called the older professor by his first name, Stavros, at his request, perhaps because he loved language and knew we would mangle the pronunciation of his last name.

Stavros taught medieval European poetry. In class one day, he took a brief detour from his lecture . . . 1/2

“Someday you will pick up the phone and an operator will say, ‘This is a collect call’ from a former classmate or neighbor you haven’t heard from in many years. You will deduce that this person is now in trouble.”

"When that call comes," Stavros said, "accept the charges." 2/2

@CollegeBoard While the linked item might look like an enthusiastic piece of reporting from a major world newspaper, there way down at the bottom of the article The TOI confirms at last that this was actually a paid advertisement. [link]
@davewiner Other lives to live.
February 6
A analogy for how society works when information floats free of context. "So that happened." [34 second clip.] [link]
Remember newspapers? NPR's Scott Simon gently mentions a problem with news paywalls. [link]
February 5
Wendell Berry on the basics. [link]

"Disinformation, of course, is utterly free." NPR's Scott Simon on the proliferation of paywalls on news sites, making reliable news harder for millions to find. No hint in this essay that anyone on the earth has thought about solutions. [link]
February 4

“If the rich could hire other people to die for them, the poor would make a wonderful living.” 

Said to be a Yiddish proverb.

Hard to tell what’s left out of the documentary, but early takes of Don’t Let Me Down went for a kind of pretty or lyrical feel, but in later takes Lennon started belting out the chorus, and the arrangement started to take guidance from the, what?, rawness of that, I think.

Creative process often seems to work that way. An early draft approximates something, often in a general or predictable or off-the-shelf way, but inside that draft a spark of something fresh might be heard by those who listen openly, and that spark marks a possible path forward.
A theory of social process there in the last sentence. [link]
February 3
Bit of a trend... [link]
@toebean_peets I wrote an essay once about the end of bedtime reading . . .
. . . things we’re all too young to know . . . [link]

Most unusual thing held by a magnet to the front of your fridge?

On our fridge, it’s a worn old business card from someone currently serving time in federal prison for white collar crime.

My French is poor but I believe this magnificent and vulnerable thread is about meeting people at one of life’s extremes and, with the help of poetry, forming and speaking there some much-needed and longed-for messages. [link]
@davewiner My friend’s copy of the album didn’t list Her Majesty in the song list so for years he thought the lyrics went went, “I imagine she’s a pretty nice girl . . .”
The Beatles song in which the three guitarists rotate playing lead guitar, and there’s that drum solo too. [link]
. . . Starting at about 0:54, they each take three turns. [link]

@davewiner One user’s perspective

They changed settings so many times that a user chose . . . they never understood what people valued in their product and never trusted users to point out by our choices what the real value to us actually was. FB didn’t believe FB’s own communitarian hype.

Seems like layers of crazy are laced into this: If I read the paper correctly, Wall Street was disappointed in the $10.3 billion quarterly profit report on $33.7 billion revenue for Facebook/Meta. [link]
@LV_doeshair @crzydoglady4 I have lived a couple of places in the Midwest where it was very easy on a family outing to the right park for a child to find a fossil.

@LV_doeshair @crzydoglady4 Obviously, a good natural history museum will have a couple of rooms aimed directly at this young person’s interest in rocks, gems, fossils, strata, the rise and fall of mountains, the shifting of continents, and such things, and of course a good librarian can help too…
February 1
@jill_christman @emilyfmaloney @SarahViren I completed the Iowa program in 1982, but it was an MA then, not yet an MFA. The final project was a collection of essays or nonfiction pieces.
